node.bodyHTML:
Summary

This attempts to address #10398 – trying to mock modules with different casing than the actual file prevents the mock from working, but only on case sensitive file systems.

After resolving the module, there's a check for whether the casing is different, in which case we do console.warn() to let the developer know about this.

I didn't want to outright fail the resolution, that sounds too aggressive to me and would cause issues for developers. I expect it's enough to log a warning.

I would like a suggestion on how to get the warning to the reporter! Then I can put some color on it as well, it isn't very noticeable at the moment (see screenshot below).

Test plan

My basic setup for testing it out:

index.js:

function sum(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

module.exports = sum;

index.test.js:

const sum = require("./index");

test("add 1 and 2 to make 3", () => {
  jest.mock("./INDEX", () => ({ get: jest.fn(() => 1000) })); // Note INDEX vs index
  expect(sum(1, 2)).toBe(3);
});

Configure package.json:

"scripts": {
    "test": "jest"
}

yarn link the jest-cli package

yarn link jest-cli in my test

Then in shell:

$ cd path/to/jest/packages/jest-cli

$ yarn link

$ cd path/to/JestTest

$ yarn link jest-cli

$ yarn test

The output:
node.title: fix: warn if a module has a different casing in the file system

node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Upon reading the documentation about the @jest-environment annotation, I had to find out how to use a custom class on another website, so I thought I'd add what I learned to the docs for the next developer looking for the same answer.

The docs explain how to use node or jsdom, but not how to refer to your own class in the annotation. I added some text and a code example, and added the example to an existing code snippet.

(I completed the CLA.)
node.title: Added explanation on how to use custom @jest-environment to docs

node.bodyHTML:
• add a new errors object reference to describe blocks for conditionally running beforeAll and afterEach hooks depending on the describe block setup status.

  • skip test retry on failed beforeAll setup

  • add errors to all child describe blocks and tests when a parent describe block hook throws an error.

  • add snapshot tests to show execution behaviour when a beforeAll hook fails.

  • fix typo in packages/jest-circus/src/__tests__/hooks.test.ts, exectued -> executed

Summary

A failing beforeAll hook will mark all child tests for failure. Currently when a beforeAll hook fails, the sibling and child beforeAll hooks will still run and so will the afterEach hooks of the child tests.

Test plan

I added a few snapshot tests demonstrating the expected flow.

Issues: #10774
node.title: fix(jest-circus): add fast fail behaviour for beforeEach hooks

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

In strict unhandled rejections mode (https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html#cli_unhandled_rejections_mode), the stack trace of unhandled rejection is not displayed in the console. This mode is default in Node.js 15.

To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

  1. Run a test with an unhandled rejection, for example:
test("foo", () => {
  Promise.reject(new Error());
  expect(1).toBe(1);
});
  1. The output is:
 RUNS  ./index.test.js
node:internal/process/promises:218
          triggerUncaughtException(err, true /* fromPromise */);
          ^

[UnhandledPromiseRejection: This error originated either by throwing inside of an async function without a catch block, or by rejecting a promise which was not handled with .catch(). The promise rejected with the reason "Error".] {
  code: 'ERR_UNHANDLED_REJECTION'
}

Expected behavior

The stack trace is displayed in the console.

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

https://github.com/vkrol/jest-unhandled-rejection-stack-trace

envinfo

  System:
    OS: Windows 10 10.0.19042
    CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700 CPU @ 3.40GHz
  Binaries:
    Node: 15.1.0 - ~\scoop\apps\nodejs\current\node.EXE
    Yarn: 1.22.5 - ~\scoop\apps\yarn\current\Yarn\bin\yarn.CMD
    npm: 7.0.8 - ~\scoop\apps\nodejs\current\npm.CMD
  npmPackages:
    jest: 26.6.3 => 26.6.3
node.title: Do not filter out stack trace for unhandled rejections

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

I have written a middleware stack derived from express.js. The idea is to have an express-like function stack for arbitrary uses cases. While unit testing this project, I've come across a bewildering issue. The first 12 test suites that I wrote behave as expected (they fail when they should fail and pass when they should pass). But the 13th test suite passes unless I console.log( bad_value ) just before the expect( bad_value ).toBe( good_value )

To Reproduce

NO idea. All test suites prior to the 13th behave as expected. I can't imaging why the number of test suites would matter...

Expected behavior

I expect expect() statements inside of nonce functions to execute synchronously. such as follows

	const S = new Stack();

	S.use( () => {
		throw new Error( "FAIL" );
	});

	S.use( ( err, data, next ) => {
		expect( err.message ).toBe( "PASS" ); // Should fail, but always passes
		next( err )
	}) ;
       
       S.dispatch() // Calls all functions passed to S.use() synchronously, and FIFO order

StackOverflow

Look at the last test in this repl.it

envinfo

  System:
    OS: Linux 5.4 Ubuntu 20.04.1 LTS (Focal Fossa)
    CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4710HQ CPU @ 2.50GHz
  Binaries:
    Node: 12.16.3 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.16.3/bin/node
    npm: 6.14.8 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.16.3/bin/npm
  npmPackages:
    jest: ^26.6.1 => 26.6.1
node.title: Assertion fails unless I console.log the expected value before the expect() statement (code is synchronous)

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

In the latest version of Jest (26.6.3) new Float32Array( 1 ).buffer instanceof ArrayBuffer returns false causing tests to fail.

To Reproduce

The following test fails in v26.6.3 but passes in v25.5.4 with no extra configuration:

describe('Float32Array.buffer', () => {
    it('should be an instance of ArrayBuffer', () => {
        expect(new Float32Array().buffer instanceof ArrayBuffer).toBeTruthy();
    });
});

Expected behavior

That new Float32Array().buffer instanceof ArrayBuffer return true like it does in the browser and node.

envinfo

  System:
    OS: macOS High Sierra 10.13.6
  Binaries:
    Node: 13.8.0
    Yarn: 1.10.1
    npm: 6.13.7
  npmPackages:
    jest: ^26.6.3 => 26.6.3
node.title: Float32Array.buffer instanceof ArrayBuffer returns false in latest release

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

// index.ts
type Config = {
    clusters: { [id in string]: string };
    helpMenu: {
        open: boolean;
    };
};

const getDefaultClusters = (clusters: Config["clusters"]) => {
    return new Proxy(clusters, {
        get() {
            return "foo";
        },
    });
};

export const DEFAULT_CONFIG = {
    clusters: getDefaultClusters({}),
    helpMenu: {
        open: true,
    },
};

export const getDefaultConfig = (openMenu: boolean): Config => {
    return {
        ...DEFAULT_CONFIG,
        helpMenu: {
            open: openMenu,
        },
    };
};
// index.test.ts
import { DEFAULT_CONFIG, getDefaultConfig } from "./index";

test("config", () => {
    expect(DEFAULT_CONFIG).toEqual(DEFAULT_CONFIG);
});

test("config wrapped in function", () => {
    expect(getDefaultConfig(true)).toEqual(getDefaultConfig(true));
});
 FAIL  src/index.test.ts
  ✓ sanity
  ✓ config
  ✕ config wrapped in function (1 ms)

  ● config wrapped in function

    TypeError: b[IteratorSymbol] is not a function

      10 | 
      11 | test("config wrapped in function", () => {
    > 12 |     expect(getDefaultConfig(true)).toEqual(getDefaultConfig(true));
         |                                    ^
      13 | });
      14 | 

      at Object.<anonymous> (src/index.test.ts:12:36)

Test Suites: 1 failed, 1 total
Tests:       1 failed, 2 passed, 3 total
Snapshots:   0 total
Time:        1.596 s
Ran all test suites.

Why is it that the test named config testing the equality of DEFAULT_CONFIG succeeds but the test config wrapped in function fails? The only difference is that a function returns DEFAULT_CONFIG.

To Reproduce

The example above can be reproduced here: https://github.com/vai0/ts-jest-proxy

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

  1. clone repo
  2. run npm install
  3. run npm run test:watch

Expected behavior

Expect that the test handle objects with Proxy values returned from a function.

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

https://github.com/vai0/ts-jest-proxy

envinfo

System:
    OS: Linux 4.19 Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster) 10 (buster)
    CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-7820HQ CPU @ 2.90GHz
  Binaries:
    Node: 12.14.0 - /tmp/fnm-shell-8205872/bin/node
    npm: 6.13.4 - /tmp/fnm-shell-8205872/bin/npm
  npmPackages:
    jest: 26.6.3 => 26.6.3
node.title: Jest complains when function returning object containing a Proxy is tested with isEqual

node.bodyHTML:
Hi there, I am trying to create a web application with React and I am currently using jest to test my React app. However, there is a feature where I am using the MediaRecorder Api to record a media stream in the web application, so when I write a simple test to check if that component has rendered using jest, it fails because it tells me: "ReferenceError: MediaRecorder is not defined" in the application at
let mediaRecorder = new MediaRecorder(stream, options);.
I hear that jsdom doesn't have the mediarecorderAPI so I was trying to mock it, but I am super stuck on how to mock the MediaRecorder object or create a fake MediaRecorder object with a fake constructor that does nothing. If anyone has an idea on how to do it, please let me know 🙏

And Thank you for your help!
node.title: How to mock MediaRecorder API in Jest

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

When using test.concurrent.only and test.concurrent with two different tests, the test.concurrent test runs but reports as skipped. This behavior does not happen with test and test.only.

To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

In a test file with all test.concurrent, change one of them to test.concurrent.only and rerun test for that file.

Expected behavior

When run with regular test.only, the execution of the others are not performed and the test is marked as skipped. However, with test.concurrent.only, the test does run (only apparent via side effects like console.log) but the test is correctly marked as skipped. The test should not actually run like it does with test.only.

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

Using test.only:
https://repl.it/repls/NativeHuskySweepsoftware#sum.test.js
In this repl you can see the console.log line does not appear for the skipped test.

Using test.concurrent.only:
https://repl.it/repls/WillingDazzlingCategory#sum.test.js
But in this version the console.log line does appear for the skipped test.

envinfo

N/A (used repl above for all testing)

Notes

I did not try this mixing test and test.concurrent.only but there could be an issue there as well.
node.title: `test.concurrent.only` does not work as expected

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

jest-mock's getMetadata ignores field properties when those are objects who have overridden the prototype's toString method. This has the effect of causing unwarranted runtime exceptions during tests when a test has mocked such an object.

To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

import gql from 'graphql-tag'
import ModuleMocker from 'jest-mock'

const fragment = gql`
  fragment SomeFragment on UserPostCounts {
    publishedPosts
  }
`

console.log('fragment.loc.source:  ', fragment.loc.source)

const mockMetadata = ModuleMocker.getMetadata(fragment)
console.log('MockMetadata.members.loc.members.source: ', mockMetadata.members.loc.members.source)

it('toy test', () => {})

In this case, the source property of a fragment location object is an instance of a class that provides its own toString. I believe the root cause is the function getType and, more specifically, this function:

jest/packages/jest-mock/src/index.ts

Lines 301 to 303 in 4f84f61

function getObjectType(value: unknown): string {
return Object.prototype.toString.apply(value).slice(8, -1);
}

Expected behavior

I expected getMetadata to correctly generate property information for all fields of an object regardless if a field was an object that overrode the toString function.

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

repl demo

envinfo

  System:
    OS: macOS 10.15.7
    CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8569U CPU @ 2.80GHz
  Binaries:
    Node: 12.18.3 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.18.3/bin/node
    Yarn: 1.17.3 - ~/path/to/project/node_modules/.bin/yarn
    npm: 6.14.6 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.18.3/bin/npm
  npmPackages:
    jest: 24.0.0 => 24.0.0
node.title: [jest-mock] getMetadata incorrectly drops field properties

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

The following TypeScript code

import * as employeeData from 'Source_Data/employee';

generates this error message

    Cannot find module 'Source_Data/employee' from 'src/framework/module/header.ts'

    Require stack:
      src/framework/module/header.ts
      src/framework/backend/jsonData.ts
      test/unittest/backend/jsonData.ts

      1 | import {uuid} from 'Source_ODS/uuid';
      2 | //import * as employeeData from 'Source_Framework/data/employee';
    > 3 | import * as employeeData from 'Source_Data/employee';
        | ^
      4 |
      5 |
      6 | /**

      at Resolver.resolveModule (node_modules/jest-resolve/build/index.js:306:11)
      at Object.<anonymous> (src/framework/module/header.ts:3:1)

when using this paths settings:

{
  "extends": "./configs/tsconfig_base",
  "compilerOptions": {
    "paths": {
      "Source_Modules/*": ["./src/modules/*"],
      "Source_Framework/*": ["./src/framework/*"],
      "Source_Data/*": ["./src/framework/data/*"],
      "Source_ODS/*": ["./src/framework/ods/*"],
      "Source_Vendor/*": ["./vendor/*"],
      "CoreImg/*": ["./img/*"],
      "jquery-ui/*": ["jquery-ui/ui/*"],
      "jquery-ui-css/*": ["./vendor/jquery-ui/ui-lightness/*"],
      "JQueryUIImg/*": ["./vendor/jquery-ui/ui-lightness/images/*"]
    }
  },
  "compileOnSave": false,
  "include": [
    "src/**/*",
    "test/unittest/**/*"
  ],
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules"
  ]
}

but when changing it to this

import * as employeeData from 'Source_Data/employee';

it works as expected.

To Reproduce

The problem can be reproduced at will but I'm currently not able to extract it from a large production environment into a simple example.

Expected behavior

The code reporting an error should work the same way the workaround works as the module does exist.

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

Unfortunately not yet possible but working on it

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

After upgrading from Jest v26.6.0 to v26.6.2 I started to experience missing files in the code coverage report.

I found that the problem is fixed when I re-run jest with --no-cache.

To Reproduce

I couldn't isolate the problem in a small repo, but I found that it happens very often when I follow these steps:

  1. Run tests with jest --coverage
  2. Add new tests while running with jest --watch
  3. Stop the jest watch process and re-run again with coverage: jest --coverage

The files added in step 2 are missing from the coverage report, re-run again with --no-cache and the new files will appear.

Expected behavior

I never run into this problem when using v26.6.0, so I assume that is caused by some patch added in the last version.
I also removed the whole cache directory reported by jest --show-config

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

Sorry I couldn't make a small repo to reproduce this.

node.bodyHTML:
instead of

export default {
}

which is basically useless for discovery and validation with typescript

do

import type { Config } from '@jest/types';

/*
 * For a detailed explanation regarding each configuration property and type check, visit:
 * https://jestjs.io/docs/en/configuration.html
 */

const config: Config.InitialOptions = {

also consider adding

const config: Config.InitialOptions ={
   preset: 'ts-jest',
}
node.title: jest --init include types in generated config

node.bodyHTML:
🚀 Feature Proposal

Currently the testMatch property does not work if you start the pattern with ../
Not sure if it's a bug or intended, but I would propose to make ti possible to match tests that are outside the current directory.

Motivation

I have multiple services in my project, each with their own tests file.
I also have a folder "Tests" where I put all my integration tests (and has it's own package.json file).

In order to keep it clean, ideally I would run all the test from the Tests folder.
But now I need to create a package.json file in the root folder of the project and run all the tests from there.

Example

Current solution:


-- Project 
    -- Services
        -- Service1
           --Tests
              -- service1.test.js
              -- controller1.test.js
           --package.json
   -- Tests 
       -- integration-test1.test.js
       -- integration-test2.test.js
       -- package.json
  -- package.json                <---- in here jest.testMatch: ["**/*.test.js"]

With proposes solution:

-- Project 
    -- Services
        -- Service1
           --Tests
              -- service1.test.js
              -- controller1.test.js
           --package.json
   -- Tests 
       -- integration-test1.test.js
       -- integration-test2.test.
       -- package.json                <---- in here jest.testMatch: ["../**/*.test.js"]

Pitch

Regards logic to find test files
node.title: Allow testMatch to match tests from parent folder.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64760385/adal-service-ts-doesnt-work-for-me-in-angular-when-i-run-the-tests-with-jest

Best regards.
node.title: Error with jest and ADAL.service

node.bodyHTML:
🚀 Feature Proposal

add ability to run tests related to last commit
so a CLI flag and a new option here:

Watch Usage
 › Press a to run all tests.
 › Press f to run only failed tests.
 › Press p to filter by a filename regex pattern.
 › Press t to filter by a test name regex pattern.
 › Press q to quit watch mode.
 › Press Enter to trigger a test run.

Press l to run files changed in last commit

Motivation

Because I often want to test something after it has been commited. Usually I test stuff before commit, but there are valid usecases where you want to retest last commit. Like for example when cherry picking a change from another branch.

Example

When my last commit was a change in file a.js and I run for changed files in last commit, it runs a.spec.js

Pitch

Why does this feature belong in the Jest core platform?
because it's hard to achieve otherwise

Common feature proposals that do not typically make it to core:

  • New matchers (see jest-extended)
  • Changes to the default reporter (use custom reporters instead)
  • Changes to node/jsdom test environments (use custom environments instead)
node.title: add ability to run tests related to last commit

node.bodyHTML:
🐛 Bug Report

With coverageProvider: 'v8' and coverage enabled, Jest crashes with imported but non-elided type-only modules.

To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

  • jest.config.mjs: 
    export default {
  collectCoverage: true,
  coverageProvider: 'v8',
  rootDir: 'src'
};
  • babel.config.json 
    {
  "presets": [
    "@babel/typescript"
  ]
}
  • src/types.ts: 
    export interface obj {}
  • src/mytest.test.ts: 
    import * as types from './types';

test('1+1=2', () => {
  console.log(types);
  expect(1 + 1).toBe(2);
});
  • Run npx jest 
    PASS  src2/mytest.test.ts
  √ 1+1=2 (16 ms)

  console.log
    { default: {} }

      at Object.<anonymous> (mytest.test.ts:4:11)

TypeError: Cannot read property 'replace' of undefined
    at V8ToIstanbul._resolveSource (D:\repo\node_modules\v8-to-istanbul\lib\v8-to-istanbul.js:86:29)
    at V8ToIstanbul.load (D:\repo\node_modules\v8-to-istanbul\lib\v8-to-istanbul.js:57:26)
    at D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\reporters\build\CoverageReporter.js:624:27
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
    at CoverageReporter._getCoverageResult (D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\reporters\build\CoverageReporter.js:587:32)
    at CoverageReporter.onRunComplete (D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\reporters\build\CoverageReporter.js:231:45)
    at ReporterDispatcher.onRunComplete (D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\core\build\ReporterDispatcher.js:88:9)
    at TestScheduler.scheduleTests (D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\core\build\TestScheduler.js:350:5)
    at runJest (D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\core\build\runJest.js:376:19)
    at _run10000 (D:\repo\node_modules\@jest\core\build\cli\index.js:416:7)

Expected behavior

Jest doesn't crash, and coverage works.

Link to repl or repo (highly encouraged)

    CPU: (64) x64 AMD Ryzen Threadripper 3970X 32-Core Processor
